title: CBA hit with second class action lawsuit in 2 days
text:
It comes just one day after rival firm Maurice Blackburn filed a separate action against CFS and its former director Linda Elkins, now a KPMG partner, for failing to transition members of the FirstChoice Employer Fund to a low cost MySuper product in a timely fashion.

'No justification for commissions'

The Federal Parliament passed legislation on 14 October ending a carve-out allowing financial product providers to continue paying commissions to financial advisers despite a 2012 ban on conflicted remuneration. The ban, stipulated in the Future of Financial Advice reforms to the Corporations Act, was not applied retrospectively.

“The Hayne Report found there was no justification for continuing to pay commissions to financial advisers. We agree,” said Slater and Gordon special counsel Nathan Rapoport.

“Paying these commissions – and as a result charging members higher fees – ripped hundreds of millions of dollars out of members’ retirement savings to profit the financial advisers or the licensees they worked for, who were not required to provide any services in exchange.

“We allege that Colonial should have stopped paying the commissions for all its members and reduced their fees accordingly, as it properly did for new members.”

This is the second class action Slater and Gordon has filed against CFS in the wake of the Hayne royal commission. It also has proceedings underway against Westpac’s BT Financial Group and AMP.

A CBA spokesperson told The Australian Financial Review the bank welcomes the passage of the legislation ending grandfathered commission payments to financial advisers and will “phase out grandfathered remuneration throughout 2020”.

The bank has suspended a planned divestment of Colonial First State, saying it is focused instead on implementing the recommendations of the royal commission and related legislation.
description: The Commonwealth Bank is facing yet another class action litigation suit as the Hayne inquiry fallout continues to escalate.
